title: ‘Landslide’: Santana beats out Baker, Wu says, while Culpepper wins D7
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Henry Santana secures reelection to Boston City Council, beating former councilor Frank Baker, according to Mayor Wu and unofficial results.
Rev. Miniard Culpepper wins the open District 7 City Council seat by defeating Said Ahmed, filling Tania Fernandes Anderson's vacated position.
All Boston City Council incumbents win reelection, with City Council President Ruthzee Louijeune receiving the most votes according to unofficial reports.

title: Jake Wilson to be Somerville’s next mayor, unofficial results show
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Jake Wilson won Somerville's mayoral election with 11,185 votes, defeating opponent Willie Burnley Jr., who received 9,054 votes.
Wilson will address issues like homelessness, drug use, and street safety as the new mayor of Somerville.
Wilson, a former city councilor and non-profit leader, campaigned on improving city services and has a background in media and communications.

title: Lowell police seeking public’s help with details about fatal hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lowell police request public assistance with information on a fatal hit-and-run that occurred on October 30.
A pedestrian was fatally struck by a car on Chelmsford Street in Lowell; the vehicle fled the scene.
Police identified the vehicle involved but seek further details; contact Lowell police at 978-937-3200.

title: ‘This is just the beginning’: Nonbinding Israel divestment ballot question passes in Somerville
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Somerville voters approved a nonbinding divestment question targeting companies supporting Israel's actions in Palestine, with 55.7% voting in favor.
The ballot measure, driven by Somerville for Palestine, faced opposition and legal challenges from Somerville United Against Discrimination.
Proponents, like Sara Halawa, aim to push Somerville officials to implement divestment from companies involved in Israeli activities.

title: Tom Brady just revealed that his dog Junie is a clone of Lua, his deceased furry friend
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Tom Brady revealed his dog Junie is a clone of his late dog Lua, using a blood sample from Lua.
Brady partnered with Colossal Biosciences, which acquired cloning company Viagen, to clone his deceased pet.
Tom Brady's investment in Colossal Biosciences supports their cloning technology and species preservation mission.

title: Running unopposed, Michelle Wu secures second term as her national profile grows
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Michelle Wu secures her second term as Boston's mayor after running unopposed in the November election.
Wu gained national attention for her congressional testimony on Boston's sanctuary policies and opposition to Trump's immigration claims.
Wu's administration achievements include making bus lines in Dorchester fare-free and pursuing rent stabilization through a 2023 petition.

title: Tell us: What should Mayor Wu focus on in her second term?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu runs unopposed for her second term after securing a decisive win in September's preliminary election.
Wu's first term focused on immigration, housing affordability, climate goals, and community-based public safety initiatives in Boston.
The community is invited to suggest priorities for Wu's second term, including housing, climate, public safety, and immigration.

title: ‘This is kidnapping — plain and simple’: ICE arrests 9 employees at Allston car wash
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: ICE agents detained 9 employees at Allston Car Wash despite their work permits, according to the manager.
22 federal agents arrived with subpoenas, detaining employees before they retrieved documents due to a language barrier.
Boston Councilor Liz Breadon condemned the raid, advising affected individuals to contact local immigration assistance groups.

title: Patriots opt to stand pat at trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots chose not to make any trades by the NFL deadline, keeping their current roster intact.
The team traded away Keion White and Kyle Dugger prior to the deadline, reducing defensive depth.
Patriots aim to build a sustainable contender and avoid trading draft picks for short-term gains in 2025.

title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston food businesses offer free meals and discounts amid SNAP benefit cuts during the government shutdown.
Many local restaurants are partnering with nonprofits to provide community fridges and free or discounted meals.
Food businesses accepting SNAP cards include American Flatbread, Blacker's Bakeshop, and Suya Joint for free meal programs.
